articles.title: Raise awareness of flood risk to homes | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Fiona Barbour says the government should implement the environmental audit committee’s recommendations to mitigate against unpredictable weather
articles.summary: Fiona Barbour argues that nearly half of UK gardens paved over increase risk of surface-water flooding, now England’s most common and least understood threat—4.6 million properties are at risk. She urges the government to act on Environmental Audit Committee and Institution of Civil Engineers recommendations: create a single national flood-reporting and information service, launch a public flood-awareness campaign, and enforce Schedule 3 of the Flood and Water Management Act 2010 to mandate sustainable drainage systems in all new developments. Without these coordinated, preventative measures, current reactive flood management leaves communities vulnerable.

articles.title: British summer time started in the family | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Julian Harber on William Willett, who came up with the idea of changing the clocks. Plus a letter from Jennifer Gale on seasonal affective disorder
articles.summary: In letters responding to the Guardian, Julian Harber of West Yorkshire reveals his family connection to William Willett—his great-grandmother’s brother—and notes a Petts Wood memorial sundial fixed to British Summer Time. Jennifer Gale of Devon writes about her personal struggle with seasonal affective disorder; she has logged sunrise and sunset times for years to track patterns, noting significant daylight loss starts around 15 December, darkest mornings hit in early January, improvement isn’t clear until February, and warns year-round BST would delay January sunrises to around 9:30 am in the South West.

articles.title: Offshore windfarm projects may be exempted from new UK nature rules
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Firms say added costs would mean they are unable to install enough turbines to meet green energy goals
articles.summary: Offshore wind developers may win exemption from new UK biodiversity net gain (BNG) rules for nationally significant infrastructure projects, sources tell the Guardian. Under planned Defra rules, NSIPs must deliver 10% more habitat than destroyed—by planting or wetland creation—but a loophole removes BNG obligations for turbines in intertidal waters. Energy Secretary Ed Miliband is weighing this to curb rising construction and grid-upgrade costs, safeguard clean power 2030 targets and avoid higher bills; firms will instead pay into a marine recovery fund. Environmental groups warn exempting windfarms trades off wildlife protection—citing seabird feeding grounds—against climate goals.

articles.title: Marine wildlife fleeing to poles due to global heating as Australian oceans face ‘uncharted’ future
articles.trailText: From 2040 onwards the average year for marine ecosystems is likely to be more extreme than the worst years experienced up until 2015, researchers say
articles.summary: New modelling of Australia’s oceans under four emissions scenarios shows that by 2040 the average year will be more extreme than any experienced before 2015, with unprecedented heat, acidification and oxygen loss. Marine species are already migrating poleward at roughly 59 km per decade (kingfish up to 102 km) and extreme marine heatwaves are intensifying. Protected areas are as vulnerable as open waters, prompting calls to expand climate refuges along southern and southwestern coasts and to urgently cut carbon emissions. Experts warn that ocean warming, deoxygenation and acidification form a ‘deadly trio’ necessitating new conservation laws tailored to these emerging conditions.

articles.title: Pakistani farmers to sue German polluters over climate-linked flood damage
articles.trailText: Claimants seek compensation from RWE and Heidelberg Materials after extreme flooding destroyed harvests
articles.summary: After Pakistan’s record 2022 floods—one-third of the country submerged, 1,700 killed, $30bn losses—43 farmers from Sindh have sent formal notices to German energy giant RWE and cement maker Heidelberg Materials demanding €1m in compensation for farm destruction and two lost harvests. Claimants plan to sue in December if liability isn’t acknowledged, citing companies’ share of historical greenhouse gas emissions (0.68% for RWE, 0.12% for Heidelberg) and invoking the ‘polluter pays’ principle. Backed by European human rights groups, they aim to leverage new precedents in cross-border climate litigation, including recent cases against Shell and Holcim.

articles.title: ‘Trump doesn’t represent us’: US activist groups to push for climate action at Cop30 in Brazil
articles.trailText: US groups aim to represent country at UN climate summit even as Trump administration declines to send a delegation
articles.summary: US environmental organisations led by Oil Change International, Greenpeace and the Center for Biological Diversity will attend Cop30 in Belém, Brazil despite the Trump administration’s withdrawal from Paris and rejection of climate science. They aim to showcase American public support—three-quarters back stronger emissions cuts—and to press for ambitious global emissions reductions, climate adaptation plans and polluter-pays mechanisms. By highlighting state-level wins and mobilising protests, they seek to counter US federal opposition and block efforts to undermine UN climate talks.

articles.title: World’s climate plans fall drastically short of action needed, analysis shows
articles.trailText: Recent plans submitted to UN by more than 60 countries would cut carbon by only 10%, a sixth of what is needed
articles.summary: Analysis of 60+ national climate plans submitted by October shows a combined 10% cut in greenhouse gases by 2035 vs 2019—just one-sixth of the reduction needed to cap warming at 1.5 °C. UN climate chief Simon Stiell praised some overdelivery but urged urgent acceleration. China’s formal NDC is pending despite announcing a 7–10% cut from its peak by 2035; the EU’s target (62–72.5% by 2035) remains under negotiation. The US submission is uncertain under Trump. Ahead of COP30 in Belém, leaders in Brazil will wrestle with finance for developing nations and concrete net-zero roadmaps.

articles.title: Country diary: The working day begins and ends in darkness once more | Sarah Laughton
articles.trailText: Long Dean, Cotswolds: On the farm, we’re firmly on the path towards winter – though the fields have a spring-like greenness
articles.summary: At Long Dean in the Cotswolds, Sarah Laughton chronicles the biannual muster of a neighbouring mixed beef herd from distant summer grazing back to its winter shed—an all-hands, traffic-stopping spectacle that marks the shift from autumn to winter. Blocking gateways and sealing B-road crossings, the team celebrates with a well-earned pint once cattle are secured. Meanwhile, the sow returns to her winter sty, while leased pasture remains lush after rain and mild days. With clocks back, the author laments working days bookended by darkness, underscored by falling beech masts and a lone badger’s rasp.

articles.title: Wind power has cut £104bn from UK energy costs since 2010, study finds
articles.trailText: Reduction comes from energy generated from windfarms and lower cost of gas owing to lower demand
articles.summary: UCL researchers report UK wind power cut energy bills by £104.3 bn from 2010–23: £14.2 bn from cheaper electricity versus gas generation and £133.3 bn from lower gas prices and avoided infrastructure, offset by £43.2 bn in green subsidies. By depressing European gas demand, renewables reduced global prices and curtailed the need for new gas plants. The study calls for decoupling electricity and gas pricing to reflect wind’s true savings. Industry voices warn that a planned £1.1 bn offshore wind auction budget is too low to secure future cost reductions.

articles.title: Organised crime making millions from illegal waste dumping in UK, says committee
articles.trailText: Peers say ‘woeful’ record on prosecutions has led to a ‘low-risk, high-reward’ criminal culture
articles.summary: UK organised crime trucks millions annually via illegal waste dumping and burning, peers warn, citing at least 38m tonnes mismanaged yearly. Lords environment and climate change committee labels waste sector "endemic criminality," calling prosecutions "woeful" and enforcement "low-risk, high-reward." They demand an 18-month root-and-branch review of waste crime response after uncovering failures by the Environment Agency and police, £1bn annual economic cost, £150m landfill tax evaded. Highlighting Hoad’s Wood SSSI case—30,000 tonnes dumped over four years before a restriction order—they urge urgent action. Regulators pledge tougher enforcement after shutting 462 illegal sites and preventing 34,000 tonnes illicit exports.

articles.title: ‘Change course now’: humanity has missed 1.5C climate target, says UN head
articles.trailText: Exclusive: ‘Devastating consequences’ now inevitable but emissions cuts still vital, says António Guterres in sole interview before Cop30
articles.summary: On the eve of COP30 in Belém, UN Secretary-General António Guterres warned that humanity has already missed the Paris 1.5°C target and will inevitably overshoot, triggering “devastating consequences” and tipping points in the Amazon, Greenland, Antarctica and coral reefs. With only 62 of 197 countries’ NDCs submitted—yielding a mere 10% emissions reduction versus the 60% needed—he urged an immediate, steep cut in fossil-fuel use to minimize overshoot. Guterres called for stronger Indigenous and civil-society representation at COP, endorsed the $125 billion Tropical Forests Forever Facility and affirmed a renewables revolution as an economic necessity.

articles.title: Experts say Ed Miliband’s £1.1bn for new offshore wind projects not enough
articles.trailText: One energy industry source says they expected an annual budget as high as £2bn to meet UK’s green energy targets
articles.summary: Ed Miliband’s Department for Energy budgets £1.1 bn/year—£900 m for fixed offshore turbines, £180 m for floating—to fund new projects, drawing criticism that it covers only a quarter of the 20 GW pipeline and falls short of the 2030 decarbonisation target. RenewableUK and industry experts argue a £2 bn annual budget is needed. The auction under the CfD scheme may expand if bids prove value, extending contracts to 20 years. Conservatives and Reform oppose net zero, while ministers insist the 2030 goal remains viable, stressing energy security and lower bills.

articles.title: Those who defend nature against Labour’s growth agenda are not ‘traitors’ | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The environment is not a barrier to growth, or an internet meme, says Sally Hayns in response to the government’s social media post based on the popular BBC show The Traitors
articles.summary: Sally Hayns, CEO of the Chartered Institute of Ecology and Environmental Management, condemns the UK government’s use of social media to label environmental safeguards and their defenders as “blockers” or “traitors” via a meme referencing BBC’s The Traitors. She argues nature underpins economic growth, public health and wellbeing, not an obstacle to development. This tactic undermines public trust, fuels culture wars and harms ecosystems. Hayns urges ministers to abandon adversarial messaging and collaborate with ecologists to ensure new housing benefits both people and the environment.

articles.title: Two crucial Florida coral species left ‘functionally extinct’ by ocean heatwave
articles.trailText: Climate crisis drives near-total collapse of staghorn and elkhorn corals that formed backbone to state’s reefs
articles.summary: New study in Science finds Florida’s staghorn (Acropora cervicornis) and elkhorn (Acropora palmata) corals are now functionally extinct after a 2023 marine heatwave caused 98–100% mortality in the Keys and 38% offshore losses. Diver surveys of 52,000+ colonies at 391 sites show decades of pollution and disease compounded by unprecedented heat stress. With these key reef builders lost, Florida’s reefs and coastal protections face collapse. Offsite nurseries and reseeding efforts may only delay full extinction without immediate global warming mitigation. The loss threatens biodiversity, fisheries and storm defenses as climate-driven heatwaves intensify. Scientists urge urgent action on emissions to protect remaining reefs globally.

articles.title: The acquisitions of a fortunate life have accumulated over the years. All must be culled while I have the wherewithal | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: Do I really need to replace my telephone every two years? Could my next laptop be recycled rather than brand new?
articles.summary: Paul Daley, reflecting on his parents’ traumatic downsizing in old age and his family’s repeated experiences decluttering inherited possessions—books, CDs, e-waste, unused kitchenware and pen collections—urges shedding accumulated goods now to spare heirs emotional burden and curb consumption. He proposes practical rules (e.g., if unread in three years, donate books; recycle or reuse gadgets) and considers ethical implications: in a world of systemic injustice, the privileged should redistribute surplus belongings to those in need. Daley now borrows from libraries for seldom-read titles instead of purchasing them. This personal essay connects minimalism, environmental responsibility and legacy planning.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Jamaica braces for its most powerful hurricane as Melissa reaches category 5
articles.trailText: Record-breaking hurricane expected to make landfall on Tuesday with 160mph winds, while New Zealand reels from storm damage
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, which intensified from a tropical storm on 21 October to a rare category 5 with 160 mph winds, is set to make direct landfall in Jamaica by Tuesday midday. Its slow 5 mph advance will unleash 200–400 mm (up to 1,000 mm) of rain, catastrophic storm surges and sustained high winds, risking extensive infrastructure damage, prolonged power outages, flash floods and landslides. Meanwhile, New Zealand was hit by two successive storms last week—the second prompting red wind warnings with gusts over 90 mph—causing roof and tree damage, over 90,000 power cuts, transport shutdowns, flight cancellations and at least one fatality.

articles.title: Nissan pools carbon emissions with electric vehicle maker BYD to avoid EU penalties
articles.trailText: Japanese carmaker’s deal with Chinese rival part of EU-sanctioned offsetting scheme to help head off £13bn in fines
articles.summary: Nissan has formed a CO2 emissions pool with Chinese EV maker BYD to comply with the EU’s 93.6 g CO2/km target in 2025 and dodge up to €15 bn/£13 bn in penalties. Under rules extended from one to three years, Nissan’s EU passenger-vehicle fleet will use BYD’s zero-emission credits. Similar pooling deals with Tesla and Polestar help legacy automakers average down combustion-engine output, though critics warn it may slow EV adoption and carmakers are lobbying to soften the EU’s 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel models amid infrastructure gaps in southern regions.

articles.title: Night-flying insects over UK in decline, weather radar study reveals
articles.trailText: Study of Met Office data one of first to show how nocturnal insects affected by factors such as light pollution
articles.summary: Scientists repurposed Met Office radar data (2014–21) to track aerial insects (500–700 m) over the UK, revealing stable or rising daytime numbers in the south but a 50% drop at night, especially in northern regions. Abundance was higher above woodlands, grasslands and urban areas but lower over intensive farmland and in brightly lit zones. Nocturnal declines, driven by light pollution and warming, suggest shifting distributions: northern species wane as climates warm, to be replaced by southerly taxa. Published in Global Change Biology, the work showcases radar’s potential for guiding insect conservation amid habitat, light and climate pressures.

articles.title: Country diary: A mini maze that was always in my midst | Amy-Jane Beer
articles.trailText: Dalby-cum-Skewsby, North Yorkshire: I had no idea it was here, just a few miles from home, yet its roots go deep into history
articles.summary: Near Dalby-cum-Skewsby in North Yorkshire, writer Amy-Jane Beer stumbles on a turf maze under six metres across—possibly Europe’s smallest—while exploring local maps. Called the City of Troy, its classical seven-ring design recalls Norse Trojaborg and Welsh Caerdroia. Surrounded by views of the moors, the Derwent and the Vale of York, the labyrinth sits on Viking-era Bonnygate Lane beside an ancient burial mound. Adjacent maize fields, now combine-harvested on land named Chapel Garth, mark a vanished chapel site. Walking its paths, Beer reflects on layers of hidden history.

articles.title: No reason to abandon external wall insulation | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Jason Palmer says it is vital to meet climate targets and we need trained installers
articles.summary: Jason Palmer of UCL Energy Institute defends external solid wall insulation (SWI) as critical for decarbonising 8.5m UK solid-wall homes and optimising heat pump uptake. He warns that sensational reports conflating PAS 2035 non-compliance with defects risk deterring homeowners, despite data showing just 5,900 of 60,000 government-funded installs (10%) reported issues on Ofgem and DESNZ follow-up. Rather than abandoning SWI after a decade of known retrofit risks, Palmer urges enhanced installer training and stricter quality assurance to deliver durable, energy-saving upgrades.

articles.title: The not-so-little Murray cod that could: fish tracked swimming 900km along Australia’s biggest river system
articles.trailText: Fish named after Olympic swimming champion Ariarne Titmus was most recently tracked at a section of the mid-Murray, near Belsar Island
articles.summary: A juvenile Murray cod dubbed "Arnie" travelled a record 900 km along the Murray River, Wakool and Niemur systems over two years, revealed by 2016–2024 tracking with audio tags by Victoria’s Arthur Rylah Institute. The apex freshwater predator, vulnerable under federal law, showed unexpected long-distance dispersal linked to flood-driven barrier removals, settling near Belsar Island. Findings on cod movements, including habitat shifts between anabranches and main channels, inform Murray-Darling Basin flow management, highlighting species’ cultural significance and need for river connectivity.

articles.title: Antarctic krill: how did a paperclip-sized crustacean cause a diplomatic row – and why are they so important?
articles.trailText: Russia’s arrest of a Ukrainian scientist this week over his support for curbs on krill fishing have thrown the vital role of the tiny marine species into the spotlight
articles.summary: After Russia detained a Ukrainian scientist for supporting krill fishing limits, focus has shifted to these paperclip-sized crustaceans that underpin the Southern Ocean. Antarctic krill (Euphausia superba) feed on plankton and sustain whales, seals and penguins, while sequestering up to 12 bn t of CO2 annually. In 2023 industrial fleets harvested about 500,000 t—67.2% by Norway, 17.1% China, 8.4% South Korea—raising overfishing and climate concerns. CCAMLR, which manages catches and MPAs, is deadlocked by Russia and China, prompting scientists and celebrities to call for a full moratorium to avert ecosystem collapse.

articles.title: Russia arrests Ukrainian biologist for backing curbs on Antarctic krill fishing
articles.trailText: ‘Trumped-up’ charges spark diplomatic row as scientists express fears for health of 70-year-old Leonid Pshenichnov
articles.summary: Russia detains Ukraine's 70-year-old biologist Leonid Pshenichnov in occupied Crimea on high treason charges after he backed stricter krill-fishing curbs at a CCAMLR meeting in Hobart. The Kremlin says he undermined Russian industrial trawling and aided Ukraine's delegation. Scientists, Australia, the UK and Ukraine denounce the 'illegal' arrest, cite his health issues and decades of CCAMLR conservation work, and warn he risks life imprisonment under new treason laws after being forced to take a Russian passport. Observers say Antarctic krill stocks now reach unsustainable levels amid Russian-Chinese resistance to MPAs.

articles.title: ‘Enforced veganism’: Ofcom lets GB News flout accuracy rules, say climate campaigners
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Regulator has received 1,221 complaints about UK broadcasters since 2020 but found no breaches of its code
articles.summary: Campaigners say Ofcom is ‘effectively suspending’ its accuracy code by letting GB News broadcast climate denial—calling global heating “the climate scam” and warning of “enforced veganism”—despite 1,221 complaints since 2020 and zero upheld breaches (only two since 2007). Reliable Media filed over 50 complaints since March 2024; Ofcom insists it allows robust debate. Critics contrast this with France’s Arcom, which found four climate‐code breaches in two years and fined CNews €20k.

articles.title: Don’t let the dugong follow the sea cow | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Diofel Tampoy reflects on an article about the first marine species to be eradicated by humans, the subject of a novel by Iida Turpeinen
articles.summary: Diofel Tampoy of Project Lawud at Sarangani Bay highlights dugongs’ critical role in Indo-Pacific seagrass meadows—which sustain biodiversity, nursery habitats, carbon sequestration and coastal resilience—and warns they’re critically threatened in the Philippines by habitat loss, pollution, human activities and climate change. Invoking Donna Ferguson’s sea cow narrative and Iida Turpeinen’s novel, he calls for systematic sighting mapping, biologist training and community-led campaigns to close data gaps and influence policy. He laments youth conservation groups get under 1% of climate funding and demands urgent investment to avert dugong extinction.

articles.title: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure
articles.trailText: Silicone wristbands worn by volunteers in the Netherlands captured 173 substances in one week
articles.summary: A trial in 10 European countries had 641 volunteers wear silicone wristbands for one week to measure non‐dietary pesticide exposure. Lab tests found 173 of 193 targeted chemicals in every band—an average of 20 substances per person. Non-organic farmers topped the list (median 36), followed by nearby residents and organic farmers, while those living far from fields still averaged 17. Researchers detected banned compounds such as DDT breakdown products, dieldrin and propoxur. Toxicologists warn inhalation and skin contact are understudied, mixtures may amplify harm, and real uptake levels remain unclear.

articles.title: As the Coalition shows its colours on nature, Labor faces a question: will it really protect Australia’s wildlife? | Clear Air
articles.trailText: There are some decent elements in what Labor is proposing, but the overhaul could end up as tinkering rather than transformation
articles.summary: Labor’s overhaul of Australia’s EPBC nature laws faces predictable Coalition resistance, forcing reliance on Greens in the Senate. Environment minister Murray Watt proposes national environment standards, definitions of “unacceptable impacts,” no-go zones, net-gain offsets, a new federal EPA and penalties up to A$825 million. But fundamental flaws remain: millions of hectares of deforestation evade federal scrutiny; logging exemptions persist; offset “like-for-like” rules, enforcement and EPA powers are undefined; and greenhouse emissions stay outside approval tests. Industry demands speed risk reducing rather than transforming protections for unique wildlife.

articles.title: Tanni Grey-Thompson says disabled drivers at risk of missing out on switch to electric cars
articles.trailText: Former Paralympics champion says inaccessible charging points show government ‘has forgotten about us’
articles.summary: Former Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson warns disabled motorists risk exclusion from the electric vehicle transition because public chargers often lack accessibility standards. Raised kerbs, gravel surfaces, high or slanted touchscreens and heavy cables impede wheelchair users. An amendment passed in the House of Lords would empower government to mandate accessible charging infrastructure; only 2.3% of UK charge points currently meet BSI PAS 1899. With 1.35 million disabled drivers—390,000 without home charging—and cuts looming to Motability, campaigners including EVA chief Vicky Edmonds and Motability’s Nigel Fletcher urge urgent publication and enforcement of revised standards. A DfT review is imminent.

articles.title: When trains are pricier than planes, there’s a heavy social, financial and environmental cost
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: whether it’s a holiday or work trip, railway travellers find themselves burdened by astronomical prices
articles.summary: Europe’s cross-border rail travel is hampered by high fares, poor connectivity and fragmented ticketing, making trains pricier than planes on 61% of routes despite 97% lower emissions; tax exemptions on jet fuel, VAT and chronic underinvestment have created a 25-fold price gap on routes like Barcelona–London (€389 vs €15). Greenpeace found trains cheaper on just 39% of 109 routes, and a YouGov poll shows 60% avoid rail due to booking hassles. The EU’s upcoming single-ticket regulation, fuel-tax reforms and frequent-flyer levies could internalize the €244/tonne social cost of carbon and level the playing field.

articles.title: Secret report shows likely source of ‘poo balls’ that closed Sydney’s beaches last summer
articles.trailText: Exclusive : Fat, oil and grease built up in sewerage pipes before being dislodged by heavy rain and ejected from Malabar outfall
articles.summary: Secret FOI report identifies Malabar deepwater ocean outfall as the primary source of ‘poo balls’ that closed Sydney beaches between October 2024 and February 2025. Heavy rains dislodged built-up fats, oils and grease (FOG) in ageing sewer pipes, which adhered to particles to form debris balls washed ashore via Malabar, Bondi and North Head outfalls. Population growth, more food outlets and slow-breaking vegetable oils worsened FOG buildup. Sydney Water and NSW EPA recommend better grease traps, public ‘Save our sinks’ campaigns, enhanced pipe desilting and longer-term water recycling investments.

articles.title: Country diary: A lesson in rest from the Canada geese | Josie George
articles.trailText: Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire: They are shuttling between marshland every day, honking overhead, taking it in turns to take the strain
articles.summary: Josie George notes skeins of resident Canada geese honking overhead each misty morning as they shuttle between urban-fringed marshland roosts and feeding sites around Stoke-on-Trent. She often glimpses truncated V shapes against rooftops and shifting shadows fleeting across concrete. Although largely non-migratory, their autumn restlessness, V-formation flights and rotating lead strategy for wind reduction remind her of the value of collective support, labour and rest. Their honking lifts her from daily chores, offering a poignant lesson on pacing oneself and finding resilience in interdependence as winter nears.

articles.title: Airport expansion will put UK’s net zero goal in ‘serious jeopardy’, MPs warn
articles.trailText: Committee urges ministers to set out measures to reduce carbon emissions before work starts on new runways
articles.summary: A Commons environmental audit committee report warns government-backed Heathrow and Gatwick expansion risks pushing the UK beyond its aviation carbon budgets and jeopardising net zero. MPs say existing policies won’t cut emissions to target, demand for air travel will rise, and sustainable aviation fuel isn’t yet commercially viable. Ministers have ruled out flight limits, rely on an outdated 2018 airports policy, and must now detail measures to meet climate, environment and biodiversity obligations before any runway work begins. The Department for Transport has launched a policy review and will consult the independent Climate Change Committee.

articles.title: Coffee is polluting but sewage is OK? | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Grounds for complaint | Everton stadium | Jo Aldred | Shaheen restaurant | Elitist theatre
articles.summary: Readers contest environmental and social priorities: Ralph Jones criticises a London woman fined £150 for draining coffee grounds while water firms discharge raw sewage unpunished. Margaret Farnworth laments Liverpool’s housing shortage, arguing Everton FC’s £800m stadium could have funded decent homes. Gerard Hastings celebrates his mother-in-law Jo Aldred as the Stourbridge Shuttle’s five-millionth passenger and inspiration to station cat George. John Roberts notes Bradford’s historical Shaheen restaurant–peregrine link. Keith Graham humorously redefines theatre as 'posh people shouting at posh people.'

articles.title: Letter: Joanna Macy obituary
articles.trailText: David Lowry writes: Joanna Macy wanted to keep nuclear waster visible and actively monitored
articles.summary: Joanna Macy, a Buddhist scholar and activist, championed a generational commitment to nuclear accountability. Rejecting the conventional “deep burial” approach that consigns radioactive waste to obscurity, she argued for perpetual visibility and active monitoring of nuclear byproducts. Through her writings and advocacy, Macy urged society to confront the long-term environmental and ethical ramifications of nuclear power and weapons, fostering intergenerational stewardship rather than relegating hazardous legacies to oblivion.

articles.title: Oil firm TotalEnergies made misleading green statements, court rules
articles.trailText: French multinational is ordered to remove its website messages about aiming for carbon neutrality
articles.summary: In October 2025, a Paris civil court ruled TotalEnergies engaged in misleading commercial practices by claiming on its website it would reach carbon neutrality by 2050, place sustainable development at its core and spearhead the energy transition. NGOs including Greenpeace France, Friends of the Earth France and Notre Affaire à Tous, using France’s new greenwashing law, forced the company to delete the statements, publish the ruling online, pay €8,000 to each NGO plus €15,000 in costs and face €10,000-a-day fines for noncompliance. The first French greenwashing judgment against a fossil fuel major highlights legal risks of climate disinformation.

articles.title: Gone in 60 milliseconds: dramatic slow-motion snake bites reveal clues about how fangs and venom kill prey
articles.trailText: Vipers target with precision, elapids bite repeatedly and colubrids saw their way in – and if they strike too fast, they might lose their teeth
articles.summary: Scientists filmed 36 venomous snake species striking ballistic gel at 1,000 fps to dissect bite mechanics. Vipers (e.g. sharp-nosed pit viper) unfold and ‘walk’ long fangs into prey in under 100 ms, elapids (e.g. death adder, Cape coral snake) deliver repeated bites with shorter, fixed fangs to pump venom, and rear-fanged colubrids (e.g. mangrove snake) rotate jaws to saw their way in. Occasional fang breakage (seen in blunt-nosed viper) confirms natural fang loss and replacement. Published in Journal of Experimental Biology, the findings deepen understanding of snake feeding strategies and aid conservation planning.

articles.title: Renewable energy investment should come from defence budgets, say retired military leaders
articles.trailText: Former European officers say spending on low-carbon power would make nations more resilient to threats from potential aggressors
articles.summary: Retired European military leaders urge NATO to classify renewable and low-carbon energy investment under its 1.5% critical infrastructure defense spending, framing the climate crisis as a national security threat. In a letter to EU governments, signatories—including Lt Gen Richard Nugee, VAdm Ben Bekkering and ex-chiefs Tom Middendorp and Sir Graham Stacey—warn that reliance on fossil fuels fuels price spikes and strategic vulnerability, as seen in Ukraine. They call for energy sovereignty via dispersal of wind, solar and other clean power to strengthen homeland resilience, supported by UK’s 5% GDP security pledge.

articles.title: UK campaigners launch bill to give nature legal rights
articles.trailText: Private member’s bill backed by Chris Packham and Natalie Bennett would impose a duty of care on government and business
articles.summary: Private member’s Nature’s Rights Bill, led by Baroness Natalie Bennett with support from Chris Packham, was introduced in the House of Lords on 23 October 2025. It seeks to recognise nature as a legal subject with inherent rights, impose a duty of care on government and businesses, and establish national and bioregional councils to enforce sustainable practices. The proposal aligns with rights-of-nature laws in Ecuador, Bolivia, Uganda, the US, Canada, Brazil, NZ, Mexico and Northern Ireland, and builds on UK measures like Wales’s Well-being of Future Generations Act and river personhood bids. Though parliamentary odds are slim, campaigners view it as a strategic opening move.

articles.title: Country diary: There’s something cooking in the woods | Kate Blincoe
articles.trailText: Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk: In this moment of great seasonal change, I go looking for butterflies and find a ‘feathered’ fungus
articles.summary: In Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk, amid seasonal change and mourning her 101-year-old grandfather, Blincoe watches swallows depart for skeins of geese. She notes a damp, fermenting hay bale—echoing this year’s poor harvest, scarcity and price rises. While hunting migrant clouded yellow butterflies, she finds a sulphur-yellow bracket fungus, “chicken of the wood,” on an oak: edible, chicken-like in smell and texture but stomach-upsetting for some and toxic if on yew. She leaves it for a hairy fungus beetle, embracing the woods’ autumn blaze.

articles.title: Wood burners linked to 2,500 deaths a year in the UK, analysis finds
articles.trailText: Use of wood-burning stoves and fires in homes is mostly unnecessary and their toxic pollution costs the NHS millions
articles.summary: Analysis by consultancy Ricardo estimates domestic wood and coal burning in the UK causes nearly 2,500 deaths, 3,700 new diabetes and 1,500 asthma cases per year, and costs the NHS £54m annually. While just 10% burn for warmth, aesthetic-driven use of stoves and open fires has surged, emitting fine particulates that damage heart and lung health. Extending smoke-control zones could avert 320 deaths (£11m NHS savings), yet only 24 fines followed 15,000 complaints. Experts call for stronger local powers, public health guidance, home insulation, cleaner heating and tighter emission limits (5g→3g smoke), with updated government plans expected.

articles.title: David Edwards obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Botanist and university administrator who helped to preserve tropical rainforest in Brunei
articles.summary: David Edwards, who died aged 77, was a botanist, lecturer and senior administrator at Universiti Brunei Darussalam, where he co-led the 1990 Brunei Rainforest Project with the Earl of Cranbrook, establishing the Kuala Belalong field station and permanent forest plots crucial for climate studies. As 24-year president of the Brunei Nature Society, he fostered community-based biodiversity conservation and, with government partners, defined boundaries under WWF’s Heart of Borneo initiative. He set up UBD’s biology department, became dean of science and senior adviser—expanding campus facilities. He was awarded Brunei’s Meritorious Service Medal in 2005.

articles.title: Heathrow third runway plans to be fast-tracked for ‘full benefits sooner’
articles.trailText: Transport secretary says updated airports national policy statement (ANPS) will be published by next summer
articles.summary: Transport secretary Heidi Alexander has initiated fast-tracked updating of the UK’s airports national policy statement (ANPS) to secure a third Heathrow runway by 2035, with public consultation due summer 2026 and final decision by end of this parliament. The revised ANPS will impose four Labour tests—climate, noise, air quality and economic growth—and align with net-zero targets. Heathrow and Arora must submit extra details by November before one scheme is chosen. Privately funded £50 bn costs are claimed tax-free, relying on sustainable aviation fuel. Supporters cite job creation and connectivity gains; opponents question climate compliance, economic justification and local impacts.

articles.title: Climate disasters in first half of 2025 costliest ever on record, research shows
articles.trailText: LA wildfires and storms this year cost $101bn, new study by non-profit resurrecting work axed by Trump says
articles.summary: Research by Climate Central finds that US climate disasters in H1 2025 cost $101bn—the highest for any first half since records began in 1980. Fourteen weather events each exceeded $1bn, led by January’s LA wildfires ($61bn, 16,000 buildings destroyed, ~400 indirect deaths). Climate Central, led by former NOAA scientist Adam Smith, revived the NOAA billion-dollar disaster dataset retired under Trump. With damages rising from $299bn (1985–95) to $1.4tn (2014–24), experts warn FEMA cuts have eroded US disaster response amid intensifying extremes.

articles.title: RFK Jr railed against ultra-processed foods. Trump’s policies encourage their production
articles.trailText: Experts say the administration’s Maha agenda ‘betrays the public’ and doesn’t actually seek to regulate junk food
articles.summary: As health secretary, RFK Jr has campaigned against ultra-processed foods—industrially manufactured products high in added sugars, dyes and preservatives—and named them a leading driver of chronic disease in children. His “Make America Healthy Again” (MAHA) strategy lists 120 voluntary measures (educational campaigns, dye restrictions, future research on pesticide and additive exposures) but omits enforceable limits on pesticides or the bulk of food additives. Meanwhile, the Trump administration’s $52 billion increase in corn and soy subsidies over 10 years—boosting ingredients like high-fructose corn syrup and soy lecithin—undermines reform and has drawn criticism from nutrition experts for betraying public health goals.

articles.title: Flooding and droughts drove them from their homes. Now they’re seeking a safe haven in New York
articles.trailText: Data analysis found higher than average migration growth to the US from areas in Guatemala, Bangladesh and Senegal hit by repeated climate disasters
articles.summary: A joint investigation by Columbia Journalism Investigations and Documented analyzed 9 million CBP records (2010–24) alongside EM-DAT disaster data to show how repeated floods, hurricanes and droughts since 2010 in Guatemala, Bangladesh and Senegal have driven tens of thousands—including some 1,800 Senegalese after six major floods in 2020—to cross the US-Mexico border and seek refuge in New York City. Many have settled in ethnic enclaves across the five boroughs, straining emergency shelters, but lack a clear asylum pathway for climate-displaced migrants amid tightening US immigration enforcement.

articles.title: Inside the illegal eel trade: is there a way to stop Europe’s biggest wildlife crime before it’s too late?
articles.trailText: Interviews with experts and key players across four countries reveal why efforts to stop the multibillion-euro trafficking industry have failed – and how to save the endangered fish
articles.summary: Europe’s critically endangered eels, vital to Japanese and global cuisines, are at the heart of a €2.5bn illegal trafficking network—the EU’s largest wildlife crime. Despite a 15-year export ban, live European glass eels are smuggled via evolving routes—African transits, suitcases, mixed cargo—and identified by ad hoc eDNA tests amid no global traceability system. Europol’s Operation Lake has inspected 16,000+ shipments, seizing 22 tonnes, yet poachers adapt. Stakeholders debate fishery closures vs. managed harvests; an EU CITES listing faces Asian resistance. Consumer-driven homegrown farming offers one conservation hope.

articles.title: Greens say Labor’s nature laws revamp ‘worse than status quo’ with climate impact of fossil fuel projects overlooked
articles.trailText: Private briefings confirm how Labor intends to deal with some contentious elements of rewritten Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act
articles.summary: Labor’s EPBC Act overhaul will mandate that projects emitting over 100,000 tonnes of CO2-equivalent annually disclose their emissions and mitigation plans but still won’t factor climate impacts into approvals, prompting Greens to decry it as ‘worse than the status quo’. The draft bill introduces a broad ‘unacceptable impact’ threshold, net-gain offset requirements with a new restoration fund and relaxed like-for-like rules, and proposes an expanded EPA whose powers remain contested. Neither Coalition nor Greens support the plan yet, and ministers stress compromise is needed to pass the laws this year.

articles.title: Two dead at Melbourne beach as wild wind batters state, while parts of Sydney hit by record-breaking heat
articles.trailText: Sydney’s Observatory Hill peaks at 37C on Wednesday – below the 39C forecast – as the mercury in other parts of the city neared 40C
articles.summary: Two men drowned off Frankston beach on Oct 22 amid violent winds in Victoria as SES logged 556 callouts. Meanwhile NSW saw record October heat, with Sydney hitting 37 °C at Observatory Hill; Bankstown 39.8 °C, Penrith Lakes 39.5 °C, Gosford 38.6 °C and Williamtown RAAF 39.8 °C; Birdsville reached 46.1 °C and Bourke 44.8 °C. A low-pressure trough drove 90–130 km/h gusts across SW Victoria and Melbourne, triggering warnings, emergency assistance, tree-down calls and total fire bans for greater Sydney, Hunter, Illawarra, Shoalhaven and western plains. Health, work and travel advisories issued.

articles.title: No prosecutions made after 15,195 wood-burning complaints in a year in England
articles.trailText: Campaigners say figures reveal a lack of enforcement with just 24 fines issued by councils for rule violations
articles.summary: Data obtained via FOI by Mums for Lungs show that between Sept 2024 and Aug 2025 England logged 15,195 complaints about illegal wood burning, including 9,274 in smoke control zones, yet recorded zero prosecutions and only 24 fines under the Environment Act 2021. Councils in Swale, Birmingham, Manchester, Wakefield and Dorset reported the most complaints but issued few penalties. Experts warn enforcement failures amid rising PM2.5 levels are endangering children’s respiratory health, lung cancer rates, and causing up to 36,000 UK deaths annually. Promised tighter stove emission rules remain undelivered.

articles.title: Global use of coal hit record high in 2024
articles.trailText: Bleak report finds greenhouse gas emissions are still rising despite ‘exponential’ growth of renewables
articles.summary: In 2024 global coal consumption reached a record high, driven by rising electricity demand despite an expanding renewable share, the State of Climate Action report finds. Greenhouse gas emissions continue to climb, leaving nations behind their Paris Agreement targets. Coal phase-down efforts are “well off track,” with India boosting output past 1 billion tonnes and U.S. policy favoring fossil fuels. Solar and wind capacity grew exponentially but must double annual growth rates to meet decade-end emissions goals. Progress in electrifying transport contrasts with slow gains in building efficiency, high industrial carbon intensity, and accelerating deforestation, endangering natural carbon sinks.

articles.title: Ancient elephant migration routes are being blocked off – can anything stop the rising death toll?
articles.trailText: Human-wildlife conflict has now overtaken poaching as a cause of fatalities – and is deadly for people too. Some villages are finding new ways to live alongside them
articles.summary: Kenya’s Tsavo region, home to 17,000 savannah elephants including “super-tusker” Goshi, faces blocked ancient migration corridors by roads, railways and settlements. As human-elephant clashes over crops and water surge—now causing more deaths than poaching—villages like Oldonyiro endure injuries and fatalities. Proposed highway expansions and electric fences threaten irrevocable fragmentation. Conservationists collaborate with Samburu farmers using beehive fencing, chilli deterrents, night watch and community monitoring to reduce crop raids by up to 86%, balancing livelihoods and elephant survival amid rapid development across Africa’s rangelands.

articles.title: No major banks have yet committed to stop funding new oil, gas and coal, research finds
articles.trailText: ‘The objectives of the Paris agreement are slipping further out of reach,’ say researchers from LSE
articles.summary: TPI’s analysis of 36 largest banks shows none has pledged to stop financing new oil, gas or coal capacity; most recent policy updates actually weakened climate commitments. Using 77 net-zero banking assessment indicators, banks score on just 18% on average, with 95% of metrics unchanged year-on-year. Many firms replaced firm “commitment” language with vague “ambition,” diluted disclosures on high-emission financing and fossil-fuel policies, and only half set climate solution targets. Since the Paris agreement, major banks have funneled nearly $7 trn into fossil fuels, and the Net Zero Banking Alliance has disbanded.

articles.title: Trump EPA seeks to weaken scrutiny for some of US’s most toxic chemicals
articles.trailText: New rule would shorten the time it takes to review chemicals, and alter the methodology used to assess their dangers
articles.summary: Trump's EPA has unveiled a rule to fast-track and weaken risk evaluations for some of the nation’s most toxic chemicals—PFAS, formaldehyde, asbestos and dioxins—by shortening review timelines, narrowing exposure routes and barring states from imposing their own restrictions. It would hinge risk findings on the 'Gold Standard Science' framework and assume proper use of PPE to sidestep worker hazards, potentially invalidating many assessments. Public health experts warn this favors industry profits, delays regulation and could erase hundreds of state-level safeguards, sparking legal challenges and prolonging unsafe exposures.

articles.title: Mosquitoes found in Iceland for first time as climate crisis warms country
articles.trailText: Three specimens discovered in what was previously one of the few places in the world without the insects
articles.summary: Until this October, Iceland (with Antarctica) had remained mosquito-free. Three cold-tolerant Culiseta annulata specimens (two females, one male) were trapped by citizen scientist Björn Hjaltason in Kiðafell using red-wine–baited moth ribbons and confirmed by entomologist Matthías Alfreðsson. As Arctic warming – four times faster than the global average – drives record heat, glacier collapse and new mackerel migrations, Iceland’s marshes now sustain mosquito breeding and sheltering in barns and basements. Similar northward incursions include UK detections of Aedes aegypti eggs and Aedes albopictus in Kent, heightening tropical disease risks.

articles.title: ‘The cars just turn them into mush’: can Britain’s toads be saved from traffic and terrible decline?
articles.trailText: Since 1985, the country’s toad population has almost halved, with hundreds of thousands killed on the roads each year. But many people are determined to protect them – including 274 dedicated patrol groups
articles.summary: Since 1985 the UK common toad population has nearly halved, with an estimated 20 tonnes (hundreds of thousands) crushed annually on roads. 274 volunteer toad patrols – such as Warminster’s group – safeguard Feb–Apr breeding migrations by carrying adults across roads, tallying kills and lobbying for temporary closures, tunnels and habitat protection. Yet tiny toadlets, climate-driven droughts, warmer winters and pond loss also threaten numbers. Biologists stress more targeted research and carefully designed underpasses are vital. Beyond ecological roles as pest controllers and prey, toads hold deep cultural value. Engaging young volunteers is now crucial if Britain’s toads are to survive.

articles.title: October heat records broken across Australia as Sydney braces for temperatures way above the norm
articles.trailText: Birdsville sets new high as BoM forecasts more record hot weather, with heatwave warnings in place in some states
articles.summary: In October 2025, Australia’s Bureau of Meteorology recorded unprecedented heat: Birdsville hit 46.1 °C, breaking a 1995 Queensland October record; NSW’s Bourke reached 44.8 °C, eclipsing a 1919 mark. Multiple towns across WA, Qld, SA and NSW reported highs to 44.1 °C. Sydney’s CBD is forecast at 38–40 °C, threatening its 2004 October record. Heatwave warnings span several states, triggering extreme fire danger and total bans in greater Sydney, Hunter and central plains. RFS and Fire and Rescue NSW have mobilised crews and advise residents to prepare. Energy operator AEMO assures supply resilience. Wildlife groups warn of heat stress in native animals amid ongoing warming.

articles.title: Beasts of the Sea: the tragic story of how the ‘gentle, lovable’ sea cow became the perfect victim
articles.trailText: Iida Turpeinen’s novel has been a sensation in her native Finland. On the eve of its UK publication, she talks about her compulsion to tell of the sociable giant’s plight
articles.summary: In Beasts of the Sea Iida Turpeinen reimagines the fate of Steller’s sea cow, a sociable marine mammal discovered in 1741 and driven to extinction by 1768. The debut Finnish novel—translated into 28 languages and shortlisted for the Finlandia Prize—explores human complicity in the first recorded marine extinction, tracing otter hunting, kelp collapse and merciless sea cow slaughter. Inspired by the Helsinki Natural History Museum’s skeleton, Turpeinen weaves ecological responsibility into literary form. The novel’s popularity has drawn visitors to touch the fragile specimen, prompting reflection on our impact on nature and the act of remembrance.

articles.title: Country diary: Even acorns grow strange in the misty gloom | Paul Evans
articles.trailText: The Marches, Shropshire: The larvae of gall wasps burrowed into these acorns in summer. Now they’re gone, leaving behind the weird, hardened detritus
articles.summary: Under a woodsmoke sky in the Marches, Shropshire, Paul Evans captures an anticyclonic gloom: lime leaves defy gravity beneath mist and low cloud while crows caw six times before settling in stag-headed oaks. The ground is littered with knopper galls—once green and sticky crown-like acorn distortions created by Andricus quercuscalicis larvae now hardened as the wasps emerge to seek turkey oak catkins for spring. Amid yarrow, mushrooms and blood-red haws, this Celtic landscape channels Samhain’s thin veil, where decay and renewal merge in creative melancholy.

articles.title: Nearly half of UK garden space is paved over, RHS study finds
articles.trailText: Homeowners urged to use more robust planting and permeable materials to help mitigate flood risk
articles.summary: An RHS–Gentian audit of 25.8 m UK gardens (959,800 ha, 4.6% of land) finds 42% of domestic garden space is paved (55% front, 36% back) and 18 m m² of artificial grass, shrinking habitats that host over 50 m trees, half of UK butterflies, amphibians and reptiles, 40%+ bird and mammal species, and store 158 m tonnes of carbon. Garden coverage varies (41% in London vs 19% in Leeds, 25% in Edinburgh, 27% in Cardiff). 26% of community gardens run on under £500/yr, <3% own land. RHS urges homeowners to adopt robust planting and permeable materials and calls on government to guarantee “space to grow” in new housing and boost community garden funding.

articles.title: ‘A punch in the face’: Germany’s dash for gas raises questions over climate targets
articles.trailText: Plans for a fossil fuel project in Wadden Sea nature reserve have angered local people and campaigners, as political enthusiasm for renewables wanes
articles.summary: A joint Dutch-German venture led by One-Dyas secured approval to extract 13 billion m³ of gas outside the Wadden Sea nature reserve off Borkum, stirring anger among residents and Fridays for Future activists. They say drilling undermines Germany’s 2045 carbon-neutrality and IEA warnings against new fossil projects. Since Russia’s war in Ukraine, the new CDU-SPD coalition, under economy minister Katherina Reiche, has accelerated domestic gas plans—including 20 GW of gas plants by 2030—and proposed scaling back renewables. Legal battles continue over a cable through a reef to power the electrified platform, amid accusations of “greenwashing.”

articles.title: ‘Next great leap’: grassroots movement to wild East Anglia goes national
articles.trailText: Set up by three ‘eco-anxious’ farmers, WildEast has created UK-wide version of pledge to encourage people to restore nature
articles.summary: Three eco-anxious farmers founded WildEast five years ago, committing at least 20% of their East Anglia land to rewilding. Now they’ve launched Wild Kingdom’s UK-wide “map of dreams” platform for pledges to restore gardens, schoolyards, farms and commons. Co-founder Lord Somerleyton has converted 25% of his 2,023-ha estate to biodiversity, recording 904 moth species, 33 red-list birds and six endangered amphibians. Dozens of communities—Hadleigh High School, Wenhaston village and Five Rod Farm—are pledging ponds, woods and hedges. Wild Kingdom centralises these volunteer-driven conservation acts to boost landscape connectivity and inspire more nature recovery nationwide.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Eight dead as Tropical Storm Fengshen hits Philippines
articles.trailText: Tens of thousands evacuated amid significant damage from intense rainfall and storm surge
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Fengshen made landfall near Gubat in southern Luzon on Oct 20, unleashing intense rainfall, storm surge and 2 m waves. Eight people died—five when a tree crushed a house in Pitogo—and 27,000 residents were evacuated from Albay after Pagasa issued moderate coastal flooding warnings. Fengshen follows a series of deadly earthquakes in Cebu and Mindanao. It will cross the Philippines, enter the South China Sea and is forecast by the JTWC to strengthen to 70 mph as it turns southwest toward Vietnam, which endured Typhoons Kajiki and Bualoi earlier this season. Meanwhile, the northeast monsoon has begun, bringing heavy (100–150 mm) rain and flood risks to India’s east coast with a potential Bay of Bengal cyclone on the horizon.

articles.title: ‘It’s madness’: bat enthusiasts fear planning bill will derail years of conservation
articles.trailText: Research project team say Labour’s proposed nature restoration fund would end up being a ‘pay-to-destroy system’
articles.summary: Outside Heathrow’s Bedfont Lakes park, veteran conservationists Patty and Brian Briggs inspect their Nathusius’ pipistrelle bat boxes—only 5 of 37 occupied—as they warn that Labour’s planning and infrastructure bill, set for a final House of Lords reading, threatens decades of species protection. The bill would let developers build on protected sites by buying into a ‘nature restoration fund’, a ‘pay-to-destroy’ scheme they fear won’t safeguard critical colonies. Without local habitat, fragmented bat groups can’t thermoregulate for pups. The Briggs, who pioneered humane bat anaesthesia and rescue since the 1980s, decry the plan as ‘madness.’

articles.title: Country diary: The salty symphony of waders in autumn | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Snettisham, Norfolk: The spectacle is magnificent enough, but this time it was the sounds that moved me, of curlews, whimbrels, skylarks and knots
articles.summary: At Snettisham RSPB reserve on the Wash, Mark Cocker celebrates the twice-daily autumn roost of some 250,000 waders—knots, godwits, curlews, whimbrels, oystercatchers and skylarks. He foregrounds the orchestral soundscape: knots’ wind-tunnel thrums, oystercatchers’ metallic clang, curlews’ looping calls, whimbrels’ percussive piping and skylarks’ dry warbles. Amid this “salty Stravinsky” emerges a lone linnet’s liquid note, a fleeting sweetness in a grand, ever-shifting avian symphony. He notes their episodic, sub-flock movements with the tides, unfolding calmly every 12 hours through autumn and winter.

articles.title: East coast to sizzle after record October temperatures in Australia’s west
articles.trailText: Multiple locations across Australia’s eastern states are facing temperatures up to 18C above average over the coming week, BoM says
articles.summary: Record October heat in WA and SA—Telfer 44.3 °C, Warburton 43.9 °C, Ernabella 40.9 °C, Tarcoola 43.9 °C—shifts east this week, fueling potential record-breaking highs 10–18 °C above average across South Australia, Queensland and NSW. Outback towns (Oodnadatta, Moomba, Marree, Ballera, Flowers Gap) could scorch toward 45 °C; Birdsville, Tibooburra, Coonamble and Bathurst face extremes, while Sydney and Brisbane may peak in the high 30s. Accompanying thunderstorms risk damaging gusts in southern Victoria, southeast SA and the NSW coast, with elevated fire danger through WA, QLD, SA and NSW. Bureau warns climate warming intensifies extremes.

articles.title: Developers encroach on 2,000-year-old Devon wetland citing ‘blockages’ to Labour’s housing plans
articles.trailText: According to planning conditions, Wolborough Fen in Newton Abbot must be protected as groundworks are prepared for 1,200 homes
articles.summary: Wolborough Fen, a 2,000-year-old SSSI wetland in Newton Abbot, Devon, faces encroachment by Vistry Group as they clear land for 1,200 homes. Developers argue strict planning conditions blocking expansion and have resumed bulldozing after a temporary stop notice expired, seeking ministerial intervention to lift wetland safeguards. Teignbridge council and Devon Wildlife Trust warn works breach protections requiring proof no harm to the fen’s rare flora and fauna. Vistry insists limited works comply, while MHCLG pushes to unblock barriers to meet 1.5m new homes targets.

articles.title: Regulators overlooking toxic Pfas found around Lancashire chemicals plant
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Environment Agency not testing for ‘forever chemical’ made by factory despite evidence of emissions
articles.summary: Independent sampling detected AGC Chemicals’ EEA-NH4 PFAS—classified as reprotoxic, persistent and mobile—in soils around its Lancashire plant, yet the Environment Agency tests only for common PFAS like PFOA, ignoring this compound despite estimates of 800 kg/year discharges into the River Wyre. Experts warn this narrow focus underestimates community health risks and urge source-specific monitoring. AGC insists no proven harm and has commissioned a third-party site assessment, while regulators cite lack of analytical standards for EEA-NH4.

articles.title: Government aims to create 400,000 jobs through UK national green energy plan
articles.trailText: Scheme will offer training for plumbers, welders and carpenters as well as promoting trade union recognition
articles.summary: Energy Secretary Ed Miliband unveiled a national green energy plan to double the clean sector workforce by 2030, creating 400,000 jobs in five years. The scheme prioritises 31 skilled trades—plumbers, heating and ventilation installers need 8–10k recruits, carpenters, welders and electricians 4–8.5k each—and targets school leavers, unemployed, veterans, ex-offenders and fossil fuel workers for training. Grants and contracts will require good jobs with collective bargaining rights. Initiatives include five technical excellence colleges, £2.5m for skills pilots, a veteran matching programme and £20m upskilling fund for oil and gas staff.

articles.title: ‘There were stoats in kitchen cupboards’: AI deployed to help save Orkney’s birds
articles.trailText: Stoats have been an existential threat to Orkney’s rare birds but technology is helping to eradicate them
articles.summary: Using AI-trained heat-detecting cameras and mobile alerts, the RSPB’s £16m Orkney Native Wildlife Project aims to eradicate stoats, invasive predators that have devastated the islands’ seabirds, hen harriers and Orkney voles since arriving in 2011. Combining 30+ thermal cameras, 9,000 lethal traps and tracking dogs, teams have removed nearly 8,000 stoats across 58,000ha since 2019. Early results show curlew hatching rates up 1,267%, vole activity +218% and hen harrier numbers +64%. Sourced from New Zealand, the real-time system distinguishes stoats from other species, guiding December’s mop-up phase to eliminate the final 5%.

articles.title: World’s landscapes may soon be ‘devoid of wild animals’, says nature photographer
articles.trailText: Margot Raggett, whose latest compilation shows animals scrubbed from natural habitats, calls for rethink on UK accelerated housebuilding
articles.summary: Wildlife photographer Margot Raggett, founder of the Remembering Wildlife series, has raised £1.2m in ten years but warns that global policy roll-backs—from US withdrawal from the Paris accord to UK pledges to scrap the 2050 net-zero target—could leave landscapes devoid of wild animals. Her new book, Ten Years of Remembering Wildlife, pairs original and digitally scrubbed images of polar bears, cheetahs and pangolins to illustrate rapid declines. She calls for a “massive pause” on England’s 1.5m-home building plan, favoring brownfield redevelopment to protect habitats, and spotlights ongoing poaching crises—from Kenyan elephants to South African rhinos—underscoring the need to curb demand in Asia.

articles.title: Country diary: Racing peregrines among the rusting mills | Richard Smyth
articles.trailText: Manningham, Bradford: Twenty-six years after this great industrial hub closed down, it still has resonances with the community via its thrilling wildlife
articles.summary: At Bradford’s former silk mill in Manningham, half-restored Lister’s Pride and derelict floors sprouting buddleia and hart’s-tongue ferns with winding fox trails have become a wildlife refuge. Volunteers installed a nesting tray on the 76m chimney, enabling peregrines to rear two chicks this spring and inspiring the Bradford Peregrine Trail across post-industrial landmarks. Below, pigeons, black-headed gulls and juvenile common gulls forage on concrete lawns. The mill’s rusted iron and architecture resonate with Bradford’s British-Pakistani heritage, recalling its migrant labour history while celebrating urban biodiversity.

articles.title: World’s oceans losing their greenness through global heating, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers say decline in phytoplankton suggests weakened planetary capacity to absorb carbon dioxide
articles.summary: Using deep-learning analysis of satellite and ship data from 2001 to 2023, researchers led by Di Long (Tsinghua) and Michael Mann (UPenn) found low- to mid-latitude ocean chlorophyll fell by about 0.35 μg/m3 annually—twice as much in coastal zones, fourfold near estuaries—corresponding to a 0.088% yearly drop in carbon sequestration (~32 Mt). Warming-driven stratification limits nutrient upwelling, reducing phytoplankton, oxygen and food-chain support. This overturns prior algal-bloom studies and raises emissions-reduction pressure. Scientists urge tighter management of agricultural runoff, sewage, deforestation and coastal pollution to bolster the ocean’s CO2 sink.

articles.title: Shipping emissions levy shelved as countries bow to US pressure
articles.trailText: Long-planned charge on greenhouse gas emissions postponed as Trump officials accused of intimidation tactics
articles.summary: Under intense US-led pressure—including threats of tariffs, penalties and visa bans—a majority of IMO delegates voted 57-49 (with 21 abstentions) in London to delay a planned CO₂ levy on shipping for one year. First approved in April, the measure would have charged shipowners per tonne of greenhouse gases, raising an estimated $10bn annually to fund cleaner fuels, vessel upgrades and port modifications. Petrostate allies such as Saudi Arabia backed the US campaign, drawing criticism from small developing nations and NGOs. The postponement stalls global shipping’s decarbonisation roadmap, forcing a reconvened vote in 2026 amid industry uncertainty.

articles.title: Many people go their whole lives without seeing a platypus in the wild. We just saw four in one night
articles.trailText: Ten platypuses were reintroduced into Sydney’s Royal national park in 2023. This week, two new juveniles were discovered, leading one researcher to cry ‘Oh, give me a hug’
articles.summary: Researchers from UNSW reintroduced 10 platypuses into Sydney’s Royal National Park in 2023. Using transmitters and nets, they captured four in one night, including two new juveniles—the second and third young seen there in 50 years—signs of breeding success. They microchip, sample and anaesthetise each animal, updating transmitters for ongoing monitoring. Despite one mortality, the project, funded by government, WWF and Peabody Energy, demonstrates a self-sustaining population, supported by Yuin elder Dean Kelly as vital for conservation.

articles.title: Overconsumption and ruin: before and after images visualise how tech could harm our planet
articles.trailText: From Venice to the Iguazu Falls, an exhibition in London illustrates the hidden cost of our gadgets and devices
articles.summary: At London’s Last Shot Gallery, Back Market and UCL scientist Mark Maslin unveil striking before-and-after visualisations of Venice, the Giant’s Causeway, Iguazu Falls and the Seine under low- and high-end climate scenarios. Highlighting tech’s 6% share of human-driven emissions—double aviation—Maslin’s modelling exposes damage from mining tantalum, cobalt and tin and from e-waste methane, CO₂ and toxins. The show underscores EU moves on universal chargers and repairability rules versus industry pushback, and UK regulations since 2021. With a record 62 Mt of e-waste in 2022, Back Market’s Luke Forshaw urges sustainable, long-lived devices. The exhibition opens 17 Oct in Fitzrovia, London, calling for awareness of everyday gadget impacts.

articles.title: Gavin Newsom’s veto on bill to ban Pfas hands industry a win, advocates fear
articles.trailText: Decision from governor, eyeing presidential bid, could echo across US as similar bans considered in states like New York
articles.summary: Gavin Newsom vetoed a California bill to ban PFAS ‘forever chemicals’ in cookware, cleaning supplies, kids’ products, dental floss, food packaging and ski wax, citing concerns over consumer costs and product availability. Advocates warn the decision—pushed by cookware lobbyists and celebrity chefs—undercuts momentum for similar bans in New York, Illinois and other states where PFAS restrictions are advancing. PFAS has been linked to cancer, birth defects and immune issues. Despite the setback, activists and retailers phasing out PFAS see rising public demand sustaining future bans.

articles.title: Government U-turns on support for bird-friendly swift bricks in new homes
articles.trailText: Housing minister Steve Reed refuses to back mandating measure, despite giving support while in environment job
articles.summary: Labour’s housing secretary Steve Reed has U-turned on mandating £35 swift bricks in every new home, reversing his backing as environment secretary. His department now rejects Zac Goldsmith’s Lords amendment—supported by Michael Gove, Thérèse Coffey and campaigner Hannah Bourne-Taylor—opting for non-binding planning guidance and developer consultations, claiming this will boost installations. Critics argue weak enforcement undermines efforts to reverse a 66% swift decline since 1995: a University of Sheffield study found 75% of bird/bat box planning conditions go unmet, with no clear monitoring system.

articles.title: What the datacenter boom means for America’s environment – and electricity bills
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: from Google to Amazon to OpenAI, the economic and climate cost of datacenters continues to grow
articles.summary: America’s rapid AI datacenter build-out by Google, Amazon, Microsoft, OpenAI and others is set to triple in power demand to over 14% of US electricity by 2030—equivalent to running six cities—and force utilities to lean on fossil fuels under the Trump administration, reversing decades of clean-energy gains and potentially doubling data-center emissions by 2035. Beyond climate risks, facilities in hotspots such as Virginia and Texas consume billions of gallons of water for cooling and are driving up household bills by roughly 8% over five years. Growing voter opposition across parties suggests cost-of-living worries may be the decisive brake on expansion.

articles.title: Wood burning and gas cooking hugely costly to healthcare systems, New Zealand study finds
articles.trailText: Experts suggest replacing gas hobs with electric ones, saying it is a win–win for health and the climate
articles.summary: Peer-reviewed New Zealand research estimates indoor air pollution from 523,000 wood burners causes 446 hospitalisations, 101 early deaths annually; gas cooking leads to over 1,000 admissions, 208 fatalities and 3,000 new childhood asthma cases. Open fires impose NZ$53,400 per four-person household each year in health and economic losses; modern wood stoves NZ$1,800; gas hobs NZ$9,200. Outdoor emissions add NZ$3,200 per stove and NZ$26,800 per open fire. Researchers urge switching to electric cooktops and avoiding new gas or wood appliances to cut healthcare costs and climate impacts.

articles.title: Country diary: The potatoes are out of the ground, bringing untold stories with them | Mary Montague
articles.trailText: County Roscommon, Ireland: As harvest comes to a close, I visit the National Famine Museum, an important place of myth-busting and memory
articles.summary: In County Roscommon, Mary Montague marks October’s traditional potato-lifting season by touring the National Famine Museum at Strokestown Park. She explores the tuber’s 16th-century arrival and later elevation to dietary staple that fed Irish tenant families on poor soils, names heirloom varieties from kerr’s pink and golden wonder to the 19th-century Irish lumper, and scent-traces the Phytophthora infestans blight of Samhain 1845 that decimated crops, led to famine, forced migration and controversial export policies. The museum, founded 150 years later, confronts myth and memory while drawing uneasy parallels with suffering in Sudan and Gaza, asking when their memories will be released.

articles.title: Brazil to ask countries at Cop30 to vastly increase biofuel use, leak suggests
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Document sets draft pledge for leaders gathering at Cop30 summit to increase use of controversial fuels
articles.summary: Leaked draft pledge for Cop30 in Belém urges a fourfold rise in global “sustainable fuels” (biofuels, biogas, hydrogen) by 2034 versus 2024. Brazil, the world’s second-largest ethanol producer, claims these fuels will cut fossil emissions, but environmental groups warn they spur deforestation, monocultures, food insecurity and 16% higher CO2 emissions due to land-use change. A T&E report projects biofuel crops will need land the size of France by 2030 and water-intensive processes, while solar could deliver equivalent energy using 97% less land. Critics say the initiative distracts from renewables and fossil-fuel phase-out.

articles.title: Sponge, baby, sponge to deal with flooding risks | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Alastair Chisholm and Laurie Wilcockson on the steps the government needs to take to ensure we can buy and live in homes without fear of flooding
articles.summary: Alastair Chisholm and Laurie Wilcockson warn that government’s ‘record’ £10.5bn flood-defence pledge over ten years is dwarfed by over £100bn by water firms and falls short of Environment Agency’s risk estimate. They urge landscape-scale reforestation, activation of paused sustainable farming incentives, and adoption of China-style ‘sponge city’ drainage—currently sidelined to protect housing targets. Insurer concerns and conflicts between the sequential test and 1.5m-home plan expose misaligned policy. To legitimize development on low/medium risk sites, ministers must streamline local authorities’ flood-risk data access and mandate mitigations to ensure insurability.

articles.title: ‘Summer is coming sooner and it’s lasting longer’: what has the weather got in store for Australia?
articles.trailText: Abnormal heat is expected, especially in Tasmania, but a ‘tug of war’ between climate drivers means the rainfall forecast is uncertain
articles.summary: Australia’s forthcoming summer is set for abnormally high daytime and nighttime temperatures nationwide, with Tasmania having a 60–70% chance of exceeding heat norms. Record-warm sea-surface temperatures—warmest since July 2024—are expected to persist, especially off southern NSW due to a strengthening East Australian Current. Rainfall outlook remains neutral (wet/dry odds ~50:50) except wetter odds in far north Queensland, driven by a potential weak La Niña and Indian Ocean dipole. October–December brings elevated severe thunderstorm risk on the east coast; cyclone season runs November to April, and bushfire risk remains high from December to February.

articles.title: Different croaks: new frog and gecko species discovered on remote island in Australia’s north
articles.trailText: Researchers on expedition to Dauan Island heard two distinct frog calls in the rain and ‘sure enough, they were species new to science’
articles.summary: Researchers from James Cook University discovered three new species on Dauan Island (3 km²) in the far northern Torres Strait: a banded, long-legged gecko (Nactus simakal) among granite boulders and two microhylid frogs heard calling in the rain. Choerophyrne koeypad, a fingernail-sized climber with oversized toe pads and a metallic high-pitched tap, and Callulops gobakula, a larger boulder-dweller with a green tree frog-like croak, are both terrestrial breeders. Their closest relatives are in New Guinea’s central ranges; these endemics rely on deep boulder fields for thermal buffering. Findings published in Zootaxa.

articles.title: ‘When I pass piles of fishing nets, I see piles of money’: a one man recycling revolution on the Cornish coast
articles.trailText: Determined to find a solution to the discarded plastic nets, Ian Falconer found a way to convert them into filament for 3D printing, for use in products from motorbikes to sunglasses
articles.summary: Since 2017, Ian Falconer’s OrCA micro-factory in Newlyn, Cornwall, recycles discarded fishing nets—1m t/yr globally—by shredding and extruding them into 3D-printing filament with under 3% of virgin nylon’s carbon footprint. Its patented machinery processes 20 kg/hr of blue-green nylon beads, selling at £12k/t (pure) or £35k/t (carbon-fibre blend) for products from sunglasses to bike parts. Backed by £1m+ from 40+ countries, clients include Philips, Ford and L’Oréal. Falconer now offers containerised plants for harbours worldwide.

articles.title: Plug-in hybrids pollute almost as much as petrol cars, report finds
articles.trailText: Analysis of 800,000 European cars found real-world pollution from plug-in hybrids nearly five times greater than lab tests
articles.summary: Analysis of onboard data from 800,000 European plug-in hybrids (2021–23) by Transport and Environment found real-world CO2 emissions in 2023 nearly 5× higher than lab tests, cutting just 19% vs petrol cars instead of the presumed 75%. A 27% actual electric driving ratio versus 84% assumed and frequent engine use in “electric” mode drove the gap. Planned EU utility-factor corrections will narrow but not close it. Under-reported PHEV emissions saved automakers €5 bn in fines and cost drivers €500 extra yearly, fuelling debate over post-2035 CO2 targets as German leaders push PHEV flexibilities.

articles.title: Download your free official Australian bird of the year 2025 poster
articles.trailText: Guardian Australia and BirdLife Australia proudly present this year’s free downloadable poster featuring the art of Pete Cromer
articles.summary: Following over 300,000 public votes in Guardian Australia and BirdLife Australia’s 2025 Australian Bird of the Year contest, the official free poster is now available for download. Rendered in Pete Cromer’s distinctive watercolour style, the commemorative PDF highlights the 2025 winning species alongside past champions and runners-up. Designed to celebrate and raise awareness of Australia’s diverse birdlife, the high-resolution poster can be accessed via a direct link, enabling enthusiasts to print or display the artwork at home or in educational settings.

articles.title: Tawny frogmouth named 2025 Australian bird of the year winner
articles.trailText: Perennial runner up finally claims the crown in the biennial Guardian/BirdLife Australia poll, ahead of Baudin’s black cockatoo and gang-gang cockatoo
articles.summary: In the biennial Guardian/BirdLife Australia poll, the tawny frogmouth—third-time runner-up in 2019, 2021 and 2023—claimed 2025’s Bird of the Year with 11,851 votes out of 310,000+, topping Baudin’s black cockatoo (7,688) and gang-gang cockatoo (6,256). This nocturnal, tree-bark–camouflaged nightjar relative nests on large branches and mates for life. BirdLife Australia highlights its wider conservation messaging—from habitat loss threatening Baudin’s cockatoo and southern emu-wren to the upcoming Aussie Bird Count on 20 October. Rounding out the top ten were the willie wagtail, bush stone-curlew, kookaburra, emu-wren, pardalote, eagle and little penguin.

articles.title: Australian tropical rainforest trees switch in world first from carbon sink to emissions source
articles.trailText: Researchers say carbon emissions change in Queensland tropical rainforests may have global climate implications
articles.summary: New research published in Nature reveals Queensland’s tropical rainforests have flipped from net carbon sinks to sources in their trunks and branches over the past 25 years, driven by hotter, drier conditions. Although roots still sequester carbon, accelerated tree mortality and insufficient growth mean overall emissions now exceed uptake. Based on 50 years of data on 11,000 trees across 20 sites, this tipping point could undermine global carbon budgets and necessitate revisions to climate models and emission policies.

articles.title: Winner of the Australian bird of the year 2025 to be announced on Guardian live stream today
articles.trailText: Will the tawny frogmouth finally take the top perch? Could conservationist backing propel Baudin’s black cockatoo to the skies? Or will the gang-gang gang prove triumphant?
