The previous record of 61, set in 1999, was eclipsed. Meanwhile Tropical Storm Gabrielle, 800 miles east of the Leeward Islands with 72 km/h winds, poses no land threat but could strengthen amid NOAA’s forecast for increased late-September Atlantic activity.

articles.title: Why saving the honeybee could be bad news for other bees
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: a conservation success story has a sting in its tail as wild pollinators pay the price
articles.summary: Since domestic honeybees aren’t in decline, hive-keeping—like farming chickens to save wild birds—can harm wild pollinators. Research by Keng-Lou James Hung in San Diego’s coastal scrub found feral honeybees now comprise 98% of bee biomass and sequester 80% of pollen on flower opening, starving 700+ native bee species. Similar declines emerge elsewhere. Experts warn honeybee advocacy misdirects funds from at-risk solitary and bumblebees. To help wild pollinators, plant diverse, season-long blooms, avoid weedkillers, preserve nesting habitat, and reduce mowing.

articles.title: Air pollution can affect how well we sleep, scientists discover
articles.trailText: Global metastudy finds long-term exposure to pollutants is linked to shorter or lower-quality rest
articles.summary: An international review led by Dr Junxin Li of Johns Hopkins analyzed 25 studies (1.2 million adults over 45 across China, India, the US, Germany) and a pooled metastudy of nine, finding long-term exposure to outdoor pollutants (PM2.5, NO₂, CO₂) correlates with shorter or poorer-quality sleep. Halving PM2.5 could cut poor-sleep risk by ~10%. Six indoor-air studies (mostly China) showed solid-fuel users had more insomnia and short sleep; ventilation mitigates effects. Authors urge indoor/outdoor clean-air policies and recognize sleep as a core health metric.

articles.title: Revealed: ‘Corporate capture’ of UN aviation body by industry
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Industry delegates outnumbered climate experts by 14 to one at recent ICAO meeting, thinktank says
articles.summary: InfluenceMap finds ICAO’s environmental protection meeting was dominated 14:1 by industry delegates, including IATA, Airbus, Boeing and ExxonMobil, curtailing robust climate measures. Closed-door sessions under NDAs and weak offsetting scheme Corsia, which hasn’t required any credits, stymie essential emission cuts. Meanwhile, 1% of the population drives 50% of aviation pollution. ICAO’s policies are rated “critically insufficient” by Climate Action Tracker amid forecasts of passenger traffic doubling by 2042 and emissions tripling by 2050. The report urges open negotiations, science-based targets and industry accountability to meet net-zero by 2050.

articles.title: Country diary: There’s a bounty of blackberries out there – 350 species of them | Sarah Lambert
articles.trailText: Swaddywell, Cambridgeshire: This common plant is surprisingly varied. Late in the season, I venture out to pick what I can
articles.summary: In Swaddywell, Cambridgeshire, on a warm autumn afternoon, Sarah Lambert forages through thickets of giant blackberry (introduced and invasive), railway bramble, elm-leaved, slender-spined, pruinose and Yorkshire brambles, totalling six species in one patch. She notes berries staining her fingertips purple, a dock bug sipping juice and chiffchaffs flitting overhead, underscoring brambles’ ecological role. The diversity—now ~350 British species compared with John Clare’s four—stems from asexual reproduction, each mutation spawning a new taxon, some habitat- or region-specific, others invasive. With fermentation tang and mildew looming, she leaves the rest for wildlife, looking forward to blackberry gin at Christmas.

articles.title: Powerful owls’ grisly crime scenes in urban parkland remind us we share suburbia with a magnificent predator
articles.trailText: The magnificent apex predator of the night, forced out of forests into urban landscapes, now confronts yet another silent killer: rat poison
articles.summary: Australia’s powerful owl, the continent’s largest nocturnal raptor, is increasingly hunting possums in suburban parklands after forest loss forced it into cities. Witnesses report grisly dismembered prey remains and regurgitated pellets in Sydney’s urban trees. BirdLife Australia’s urban bird program manager Dr Holly Parsons says these owls now hold year-round territories in Sydney, Brisbane and Melbourne. But second-generation anticoagulant rodenticides in rat baits threaten them: 60% of tested birds have behavior-impairing poison levels and 10% lethal doses. BirdLife is petitioning the APVMA and retailers like Bunnings to restrict SGAR sales before regulations lapse.

articles.title: How vulnerable are Australia’s cities to extreme heat? Explore our maps
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Residents of western Sydney and outer suburbs of Melbourne are at particular risk of high temperatures, data shows
articles.summary: Guardian Australia reports RMIT’s new Heat Vulnerability Index—combining satellite surface temps, demographics (elderly, disabled), built environments, green space and socioeconomic data—reveals hotspots: western Sydney, Melbourne’s outer suburbs (Brimbank), Adelaide, Hobart, Launceston and Albury. The index’s two components—heat sensitivity (built environment, vegetation, density, vulnerable groups) and adaptive capability (income, education, access to cooling)—highlight local disparities. Unexpectedly, affluent but older-populated inner-city areas (Carlton, Fitzroy, Woolloomooloo) also score 5/5. Monash University links 1,009 deaths in 2016–19 heatwaves to age, chronic illness and low income/education. Researchers urge integrated urban planning to mitigate heat risks.

articles.title: Albanese’s Oprah-style emissions target aims to please almost everyone but risks falling short on climate action
articles.trailText: The prime minister has a stonking majority and a progressive crossbench that wants deeper cuts. So what has happened to lower the goal?
articles.summary: The Albanese government pledged a 62–70% emissions cut by 2035 against 2005 levels, a politically broad compromise to placate business interests (62%) and climate campaigners (70%). Critics note its 62% floor falls short of the 75% scientists say is needed for a 1.5°C path. The Climate Change Authority’s modelling, factoring in technological, economic and social constraints after renewables and green-hydrogen setbacks, underpins the range. Calls for a ‘war footing’ and sharper cuts persist, while ultimate impact will depend on concrete policies and whether ministers target the upper bound or beyond.

articles.title: The island that banned hives: can honeybees actually harm nature?
articles.trailText: On a tiny Italian island, scientists conducted a radical experiment to see if the bees were causing their wild cousins to decline
articles.summary: Scientists on tiny Tuscan island Giannutri introduced 18 honeybee hives in 2018 then periodically barred them to study competition with wild pollinators. Over four years honeybees caused an 80% drop in bumblebee and Anthophora populations. Lockups freed 30% more pollen, boosting wild bee sightings and altering foraging behaviors. These results, published in Current Biology, mirror global trends: managed and feral Apis mellifera often monopolize floral resources, threatening hundreds of native species, as seen in southern Spain and California. Giannutri’s hive ban now offers a model for safeguarding native pollinator communities.

articles.title: Whale and her calf entangled in shark net off Queensland coast
articles.trailText: ‘Heartbreaking’ drone footage has captured the moment a mother and calf became trapped. Four humpbacks have been snared in recent days
articles.summary: Drone footage off Noosa captured a humpback mother and calf entangled in a shark net, one of four whales snared off Queensland’s coast in days. While rescuers freed the pair Wednesday night, the mother still bore gear; another calf–mother duo dragged nets from Rainbow Beach to Hervey Bay and remained trapped. Griffith University’s Dr Olaf Meynecke notes annual humpback entanglements are rising, affecting mostly mother–calf pairs as they migrate closeshore. Marine scientist Vanessa Pirotta warned calves risk drowning without rapid response amid debates over shark net removal.

articles.title: ‘It’s not just our houses’: can a Scottish village save Queen Elizabeth’s coastal path from the waves?
articles.trailText: The people of Johnshaven have watched the sea edge closer and closer. Preserving the path is key to protecting their community
articles.summary: Johnshaven, a 640-resident village on Scotland’s north-east coast, faces accelerating coastal erosion that has swallowed gardens and sections of the new Platinum Jubilee Path connecting St Cyrus to Cullen. Local group Merchat, led by Charis Duthie and Caspar Lampkin, has secured £30,000 from Macphie and £40,000 from Aberdeenshire’s Coastal Communities Fund to install rock armour—£1,000 per truckload—to stabilise Beach Road and plug the gap in Scotland’s Great Trails map between Aberdeen and Dundee. With 100 homes at flood risk, they formed the Nescat charity amid minimal council support (£75k budget) despite £11.7m of national adaptation funding.

articles.title: Only a third of world’s river basins experienced normal conditions in 2024
articles.trailText: Increasingly erratic water cycle is creating food scarcity, rising prices, conflict and migration, says UN agency
articles.summary: Only one-third of river basins saw normal conditions in 2024 as record-warm temperatures (1.55 °C above preindustrial) fuelled simultaneous droughts—notably a July–September Amazon basin low—and deluges in Central Europe, Russia, Pakistan and northern India. Africa’s tropical floods killed ~2,500, displaced 4 million and caused billions in damage; glaciers lost ice equivalent to 1.2 mm of sea-level rise. WMO warns food scarcity, crop failures, price hikes and migration will worsen unless governments cut emissions, expand reservoirs and wetlands, adopt adaptive farming and early-warning systems.

articles.title: Country diary: Swallows on the wire, berries in the hedges | Virginia Spiers
articles.trailText: St Dominic, Tamar Valley: So far in early autumn, an abundance of ash keys and plump acorns – and the apple and pear trees are heavily laden
articles.summary: At St Dominic in the Tamar Valley, early autumn rains have greened cut hay and silage fields and softened stubble after an unusually early cereal harvest. About 50 late swallows gathered on wires at Corneale farm before migration. Maize growth promises winter fodder; farms remain self-sufficient in feed but buy straw bedding at £120/tonne. Domestic water relies on a century-old well as some boreholes run dry, worrying dairies and polytunnel growers. Hedges brim with ash and sycamore keys, red haws, acorns, scarlet honeysuckle and bryony berries. Oak leaves show mildew, ferns wilt; muddy ruts line lanes. A record apple and pear yield is earmarked for cider and perry, drawing orchard enthusiasts.

articles.title: What is a climate target, and how does Australia’s new one for 2035 stack up against other countries?
articles.trailText: Labor’s new goal for 2035 is for emissions to be 62% to 70% lower than in 2005. It’s less ambitious than the UK’s target but higher than in Japan, Canada and NZ
articles.summary: Australia’s new 2035 climate target commits to cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 62–70% below 2005 levels, up from its previous 47% by 2030 goal. This mid-century milestone sits below the UK’s 78% cut but above Japan’s 59%, Canada’s 45–50% and New Zealand’s 51–55%, while the EU eyes the high-60s to low-70s range. It forms part of Australia’s 2050 net-zero pledge and aligns with Paris Agreement aims to limit warming under 2°C. Experts hail it as a historic choice, balancing environmental duty, economic transition to renewables and global collective effort to tackle climate impacts.
